Thanks, all comments addressed:

* Kept the default codepath of TextIO and AvroIO unchanged - i.e. still calling WriteFiles, for update compatibility. Instead, TextIO and AvroIO are simply offering sink() and it is tested in their unit tests, and I marked the dynamic-destinations methods of TextIO and AvroIO deprecated.
* Removed FilenameContext in favor of explicit arguments. Renamed FilenamePolicy to FileNaming. Revamped the way file naming works: see the relevant section in the javadoc - I believe this is the most convenient and fully general way: common cases are easy to do, custom naming is easy to do as well.
* Reverted irrelevant changes
* To your question about watermark - it's outside the scope of this PR, but the watermark will effectively follow the timestamp of the next file to be emitted, where the timestamp is the moment the file was first seen.
The write part of this is effectively subsumed by https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/3817 . I think this PR can be closed.
@ArnaudFnr I think you were going to split this PR into multiple anyway, right? In that case, can the current PR be closed?
Is this PR in active development? Would it make sense to close it for now and reopen when there's something ready to be reviewed?

Coverage notes:

S3FileSystem - 80% LOC
S3ResourceId - 93% LOC
missing: exception handling, copy(List, List), rename, matchNewResource

copy(List, List) and rename is two LOC: copy, delete
matchNewResource doesn't do a lot

Practical testing notes:

Wrote a TextIO.Read => TextIO.Write pipeline to test lots of files and data.

Used Dataflow runner, Oregon region
GS and S3 regions are both Oregon
Workers are n1-standard-4
Autoscaling enabled, 100 workers max
No compression

Pipeline 1: GS to S3
~3000 files read from GS
3095 files written to S3
1274848854 lines
368107865893 bytes
47 workers at peak
time 11m16s

Pipeline 2: GS to GS
same input as pipeline 1
same lines, same bytes
38 workers at peak
time 5m0s

Pipeline 3: S3 to GS
input is output of pipeline 1
3150 files written to GS
same lines, same bytes
38 workers at peak
time 5m14s

Thanks Luke for your comment. I know that empty splits are valid, that is why I proposed to update the assert condition. In the Elasticsearch case, to figure out that a split is empty, it requires to do the whole scroll request (in the initial split) and then count the elements in all sub-sources slices. So it is a complex operation, so filtering out empty splits in the Source is not worthwhile. Thanks for the 50% figure, that is exactly the empirical threshold that I needed! I'll update the assert with this figure
@lukecwik PTAL

@sduskis I have organized them for now in single function but it caused the code duplication, once we move it to the BigtableConfig, it would be much nicer. I am not sure that we would be able to populate toString with data once we switch to ValueProviders because we might not have values in time when toString might be called, for populate display data should  be fine.

Luke, the AWS credentials solution you proposed, if I understand it correctly, doesn't work on Dataflow. [DefaultAWSCredentialsProviderChain](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/index.html?com/amazonaws/auth/DefaultAWSCredentialsProviderChain.html) wants to get the credentials from one of the following (copy-paste from Slack):

- environment variables (don't know how to set these on a Dataflow worker)
- Java system properties (I haven't used this)
- credentials file at `~/.aws/credentials` (pretty sure the Beam SDK doesn't support this)

I'll do one more load test this morning, with gzip compression.

I just tried to run a pipeline that includes this package, but doesn't use it. Looks like the S3FileSystemRegistrar creates an instance of S3FileSystem even if I don't use it, which means the S3FileSystem constructor probably shouldn't create a thread pool or enforce flag requirements. Now the GcsUtil class makes sense.

LGTM

Cool!
R: @kennknowles (merge)
R: @kennknowles (merge)

Have the S3FileSystemRegistrar not return any filesystems to register if the required flags are missing. You can print a debug statement as to why S3FileSystem support is not being enabled.

Having GcsUtil created within PipelineOptions by GcsFileSystem has little to do with not starting threads or flag enforcement and has more to do with no one spending the time to get rid of GcsUtil and migrate it into GcsFilesystem.
LGTM, thanks.

The [DefaultAWSCredentialsProviderChain](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/index.html?com/amazonaws/auth/DefaultAWSCredentialsProviderChain.html) is the best default to use for Apache Beam.

For Dataflow users wanting to access AWS services, they should really set one of the static credentials providers like:
* [ClasspathPropertiesFileCredentialsProvider](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/com/amazonaws/auth/ClasspathPropertiesFileCredentialsProvider.html)
* [AWSStaticCredentialsProvider](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/com/amazonaws/auth/AWSStaticCredentialsProvider.html)
* or use one of the dynamic ones and set the correct properties.

It is important to document that users need to use a credentials provider that is compatible with the remote execution location and we should make sure serializing PipelineOptions with a few common credentials providers works.

Once we are using the portability framework then the user will be able to build a container containing any files (~/.aws/credentials), additional flags to the JVM (system properties), or additional processes providing access to AWS credentials.

Apache Beam may also integrate different key management solutions as an alternative as well.

Can you file an overarching JIRA? I think this change and previous would fit under "allow Beam to build on a read-only filesystem"

R: @wcn3

Any updates on this? 

Is the general idea to head towards a per-runner Scala-version or per-project? 
I'd like to assist.

@script3r I think you could definitely help. I think the new gradle build system and Jenkins job already goes a lot of the way there, and the work might be a couple of gradle tasks and perhaps a little groovy hacking. Then we just turn off the "all runners in the same target" part of the maven build, since the gradle build covers it. The expert here is @lukecwik.

Take a look at: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/81e22da1f1805f6a6614a23e558f62b9aebfc0a5/examples/java/build.gradle#L74

This creates a separate gradle configuration per runner. Following this pattern we could multiplex any "runners" which create different artifacts depending on the scala version and similarly any artifacts/tests that run using specific runners to also be multiplexed on the scala version.

Thanks for the feedback.

CC: @lukecwik

As Spark still uses Jackson 2.6.5, I have to exclude the transitive dependency to use Jackson 2.8.9 (version used by Beam). Else, we have the following issue:

```
com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.JsonMappingException: Incompatible Jackson version: 2.8.9
```
